snippet.textDisplay: Anyone who thinks the fight was boring has never stopped foot in a ring or has any clue about what fighting is actually about. The same people saying Wilder has no technique and cant box are the same people saying Joshua was boring. No he was not boring. He fought brilliantly and formulated a picture perfect gameplan to win. Fans are delusional. Fighters are under no obligation to feed into your warped sense of what combat is supposed to look like. Ruiz has superior handspeed and deadly combination power. He is the faster fighter with his hands, but by far the slower fighter with his feet. He is also the shorter fighter. Joshua pumped a STIFFFFF HARDDDDD jab all night as he circled the ring and constantly moved away from the power hand of Ruiz. He nullified any chance Ruiz had of winning. He eliminated his best tools. That's a fucking fighter. Hit and dont get hit. Stick and move. Control the fighting range so that you are always in a position of dominance. Joshua landed many clean hard power right hands when he needed to. This is the sweet science. He didnt run. He circled his prey and picked him off in the pocket round after round. If you cant appreciate this then you dont appreciate Ali or Mayweather or Bernard Hopkins or Lomachenko. Boxing is not about stepping in the ring and trying your best to throw hard punches and knock people out. It's about sticking to a gameplan and executing. That gameplan will differ from fight to fight. Joshua has destroyed plenty of opponents. This opponent needed to be combated in this manner in order for him to win. Much respect to Joshua for dusting himself off and winning his life back. The greatest fighters ever have all used losses to become better fighters. Losing is what shows us who we really are. Great era for heavyweight boxing. Fury v. Wilder up next. Csnt wait

snippet.textDisplay:
When I look at all the heavy weights in my lifetime, these two are nothing special. Tyson takes them both out in the first couple of rounds, as does Lewis. Joshua is more into his pretty looks and great build comparable to Ali, but Ali would destroy Joshua because he had the heart of a champion. Joshua, not so.


Ruiz, wow, what an imposter. There is nothing special about him, and he certainly has no heart of a lion or burning desire to be the best. Look how he trained. This second fight was one of the more boring heavy weight fights I can remember and I go back to Ali and Liston having watched that fight on TV as a young teenager.
snippet.textOriginal:
When I look at all the heavy weights in my lifetime, these two are nothing special.  Tyson takes them both out in the first couple of rounds, as does Lewis.  Joshua is more into his pretty looks and great build comparable to Ali, but Ali would destroy Joshua because he had the heart of a champion.  Joshua, not so.  


Ruiz, wow, what an imposter.  There is nothing special about him, and he certainly has no heart of a lion or burning desire to be the best.  Look how he trained.  This second fight was one of the more boring heavy weight fights I can remember and I go back to Ali and Liston having watched that fight on TV as a young teenager.

snippet.textDisplay: Ruiz assumed Joshua would just come to him and fight his fight, he - like many others - didn't believe Joshua could alter his style, alter his fighting habits. I knew that if AJ followed that blueprint, he would lop sidedly beat Andy Ruiz and thats just what happened.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ruiz gained weight and got sloppy. He thought he would be able to bull in like the first fight.
AJ had an entire training camp this time. And most importantly he wanted his belts back. He took Ruiz seriously the second time. By cutting weight, able to work the jab all night and stay at a distance.
It was a very boring fight though.

snippet.textDisplay: To be fair in the first fight it only turned for ruiz when he caught Joshua in the ear with a hook. Before that it wasn't competitive and it was in Joshua's favor as expected. After that shot Joshua never got his feet back under him and Ruiz pounced. I think in this fight Ruiz was hoping for that exchange where he could get one of those shots and again and knock Joshua off his game. He knew he wasn't going to beat him in conditioning and power. And Joshua fought a lot smarter this time.
